titleStmt.title: John Quincy Adams Diary Digital Project

div.p: 1. Making out the last fair copy of my note to the Cabinet Ministry. I have uniformly made it a rule thus to write them off three times before presenting them.— Read Lessing in the morning, and for the afternoon, began upon two books.— Sir George Staunton’s account of the English Embassy to China— And Racine’s works.

2. Called this forenoon upon Count Haugwitz, and left with him, the Note, and my marginal remarks upon the projet which the Cabinet Ministry sent me.— Walk with Mrs: Adams and afterwards alone in the Park. Evening with a very large party, at Countess Hacke’s. Whist with Madame de Zastrow, Mlle: Hagen, and Mlle: Eichstett.

3. Undertook this morning to begin a separate journal of my readings.— But I fear it would take too much time to carry the design fully into execution, and that I shall not persist in it long.— I hope at least however, for one month.— Mrs: Brown and her daughters, and Mr: Richards spent the Evening with us

4. Mr: Catel called on me this morning; he is to give me lessons of German; for after a year’s assiduous study without a Master, I still read very indifferently and with great difficulty.— And neither write nor speak it, at all.— I impute no small part of the very slow progress I make to the badness of my dictionaries. That which I have (Ludwig’s) being one of the very worst I ever used in my life— Which is saying not a little, for I have long suffered under the curse of bad dictionaries— This one has not only innumerable faults and omissions of the author— But was doubtless printed by a person totally ignorant of the English language and never revised. The English side there fore is almost as often unintelligible to me as the German.— Called this forenoon at the Ville de Paris to see Mr: Bollman, but he was gone out.— Walked after dinner. Evening at home.

5. Mr: Catel, came and gave me his first lesson— Evening at Prince Ferdinand’s— Mrs: Adams did not go. Had some conversation with the Portugueze Gentleman M. d’Aguilar.— Played Reversi with Madame de Stein, Mlle: de Marwitz and Mr: Gualtieri.

6. Wrote but little this day, as the forenoon vanished amidst a number of trifling avocations. Excepting which however, and a short walk before dinner, past the whole day in writing, or reading. Snowed almost the whole day.

7. Second lesson from Mr: Catel.— We have not as yet fixed upon any satisfactory method for the study. Evening at a tea and dancing party at Baron d’Alvensleben’s— Mrs: A. did not go.— About three hundred persons there as usual.— Played Whist with Madame de Saldern, General Bentinck, and Count Lehndorf— Home at about ten.

8. Besides my usual occupations, which at present render every day so similar to the rest, I this evening looked over the greek and Latin prosodies, and to some specimens of English hexameters in Southey’s Letters from Spain, and Portugal, and in the 26th: volume of Lessing.— Without full satisfaction to myself.— Remainder of the Evening at Dr: Brown’s— Mr: Arbuthnot there— Letters from Mr: King, and Mr: Murray.

9. No lesson of German this morning, Mr: Catel having sent me an excuse. Evening at the Baron de Hagen’s, where there was the usual company; between one and two hundred persons.— Whist with Marshall Knobelsdorf, Count,and the abbé de Balivière— Mrs: A. did not go.
10. The queen’s birth day.— A ball at Court in the Evening.— Played whist with Madame de Heinitz, Madame de Haugwitz, and the Baron de Thulemeyer.— Did not stay to supper— Mrs: Adams did not go.

11. Weather very fine— Except a long walk, passed the day and Evening at home.— Received letters from America; and one from Mr: Pitcairn mentioning the arrival of the vessel at New-York, in which my brother sailed.— Had a letter too, from my mother.

12. Evening at a Ball at Count Schulenburg’s. Played whist with Madame de Heinitz and Madame de Saldern, and Monsr: d’Aguilar. Took a lesson of German in the morning; and am busied in writing it, by way of exercise— Wrote likewise letters to Mr: Murray, and Pitcairn.

13. Dined with the English Prince Augustus— The Prince’s Charles of Nassau Weilbourg and George of Darmstadt were there—with Mr: Grenville, and all the English— In the Evening at the party at Madame Saldern’s but did not stay. Mrs: Brown and her daughters, Miss Bruhl, and Mr: Arbuthnot were at our house— Dr: Brown played chess with me— Mrs: Brown shewed me a note from the queen to the doctor, with an handsome snuff box, which she sent him to day— She writes a very good hand, and turns a phrase in french prettily enough— Wishes happiness to the Doctor and his family, and especially that he may never have any affliction by them; which is more painful than any other— It is easy, she adds, to forgive, but not to forget.—
14. Writing to my mother.— Lesson of German in the morning.— Evening at Mr: Alvensleben’s—at a Ball— Played whist with Madame de Voss, Count Lehndorf, and Mr Livingston— Supped at Count Brühl’s.

15. Ball at Prince Ferdinand’s, at which the company went dressed as peasants and farmers. None of the foreign Ministers invited, of course we did not go.— Passed the day and Evening at home; reading Staunton’s account of the Embassy to China, and Racine’s Britannicus. Called upon
Count Haugwitz, who returned me the papers which he has had this fortnight; and appeared to be much satisfied with them.

16— Lesson of German this morning— My time will not suffice for the occupations of necessity, and those which I assume voluntarily too— I must read less, or give up all pretence of making notes upon my reading— I am continually running in arrears— Visit from Mr: Washington— Began the third volume of Staunton, and read the Bérénice of Racine.

17. Mrs: A. breakfasted at Countess Neale’s.— Called this day upon Count Finckenstein, and delivered to him the papers relative to the Treaty.— Walk in the park.— Staunton and Racine in the Evening— Received a number of American newspapers.
18— Spent the forenoon in reading the American papers.— Dined with Mr: Grenville— The company consisted of 18 persons— Generals and Ministers.— Evening at home— Read Racine’s Mithridate.
19. Lesson of German in the morning.— Visit in the forenoon from Baron Diemar, with a letter from Mr: Swan, relative to the muskets which he wants— Evening at Dr: Brown’s.— Played chess with him.

20.— Evening at the Vicomte d’Anadia’s party. Mrs: A. did not go. The company not so numerous as usual, owing perhaps to its being passion-week; on which account the balls announced are also postponed— Played whist with Madam de Münchhausen, Mlle: de Hagen and Count Charles Wartensleben.— Did not stay to supper.

21. Mrs: A. unwell— Had a lesson in the morning from Mr: Catel— I translate from English into German and from German into French, but since taking lessons, have been obliged almost entirely to cease reading German.— Mrs: Brown & her daughters, Mrs: Schickler and her Sister, spent the Evening with Mrs: A.— Lord Talbot here, half an hour.
22.— Good Friday.— Excepting a very short walk, day and evening entirely at home— Weather extremely cold for the Season.— Reading Staunton 3d. Vol. and Racine’s Iphigénie.
23. Morning Lesson of German. Translating into French, Gesner’s letter to Fuessli upon landscape painting Wrote Letters in the forenoon. Mr: Arbuthnot called and spent an hour with us in the Evening.
24. Mrs: A. very unwell— Dined at Mr: Grenville’s with a small company.— Lord Talbot, Admiral Kinckel, Count St: George and Mr: Robert Fagel.— Evening at home.—

25. Received some letters and Newspapers from America.— They brought, together with the pleasing intelligence of my brothers arrival there, much information less agreeable.— Evening at home. Finished reading Sir George Staunton’s account of the Embassy to China, and Racine’s Phédre.

26. At a sale of furniture belonging to the Marquis Parella, the late Sardinian Minister here.— Half an hour before dinner at the Casino.— Evening a large Ball at General Tempelhoff’s— I staid not more than half an hour. Spent the remainder of the Evening, and supped at Count Brühl’s.
27. Snow storm— In the Evening, at the party at Mr: Engeström’s. His house is very superbly fitted up. I stayed not long. Spent the remainder of the Evening at Dr: Browns, and played Chess with him.
28— Snow storm again. Reading American newspapers almost all day. Evening at the last Ball for the Season, given by Baron Alvensleben.— The Company not numerous— Home early—read Anderson.

29. Further Snow storm which continued almost all day.— The ground is entirely covered with it, and the sleighs again in motion.— Letters from Mr King and Mr: Pitcairn— Evening at home— Reading Anderson, and Racine’s Esther.
30. Lesson of German— Letter to Mr: Murray— Weather still very cold.— Walk in the Park. Miss Brühl passed part of the Evening with Mrs: Adams— Read Anderson.
31. Weather very cold— Day and Evening altogether at home, excepting only a walk.— Finished Anderson’s Narrative, and Racine’s Athalie

Day.— Rise, from 7 to 8. Employ two hours in the study of German— Three times a week take lessons of Mr: Catel— Spend the others in translating from English into German, or from German into French. Breakfast—write letters or journal till 1/2 past 2. Walk an hour— Dine.— Read a couple of hours—pass the Evening either abroad in Company or with company at home, or read poetry to Mrs: Adams.— Sup at 10—and play a game at chess, untill 11.
